column3: In every way the arrangement appeared to be a good one. At twelve o'clock each day Sam woke up, and at once the Old Monkey arrived with the two loaves and two quarts of Koolvat. This meal took about five minutes and then Sam had his daily exercise. He always turned a long series of somersaults along the edge of the moat. For ten minutes he whirled away like a Catherine wheel, and then at once got back into his barrow again and went to sleep.

"From now on treatment at this clinic is free," he concluded. "Dr Wolf, you tell me, is a pretty good hoof-and-claw trimmer. He will continue to treat you. If the work is shirked in any way, or there is any swindling, complaints can be handed in at Homeward on any Thursday morning after nine o'clock."

"Well, sir," said Sam, drearily, "I've been tricked. Near midnight a rough-looking man (not Beaver Hateman, I'd never mistake him) wheeled up barrow near to me, got into it, and seemed to go to sleep. Suspicious, I thought, so I watched him carefully. Nothing happened for a long time.
Opening of Distribution Scheme for goods from Lonely Tower will be at 11 a.m. tomorrow. Don't push!

column2: A few minutes before eleven o'clock
column3: A few minutes before eleven o'clock Uncle's traction engine, decked with flags, came along the moat path, with the King of the Badgers, Ira Smoothy, the Old Monkey, the One-Armed Badger and Will Shudder on board. A. B. Fox and Goodman mingled with the crowd to report any rough behaviour, and Cloutman and Gubbins stood at the entrance to the tunnel to control the rush.
